speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: SCENE I. Alexandria. A room in CLEOPATRA's palace.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Enter DEMETRIUS and PHILO

speaker: PHILO
text_entry: Nay, but this dotage of our general's

speaker: PHILO
text_entry: O'erflows the measure: those his goodly eyes,

speaker: PHILO
text_entry: That o'er the files and musters of the war

speaker: PHILO
text_entry: Have glow'd like plated Mars, now bend, now turn,

speaker: PHILO
text_entry: The office and devotion of their view

speaker: PHILO
text_entry: Upon a tawny front: his captain's heart,

speaker: PHILO
text_entry: Which in the scuffles of great fights hath burst

speaker: PHILO
text_entry: The buckles on his breast, reneges all temper,

speaker: PHILO
text_entry: And is become the bellows and the fan

speaker: PHILO
text_entry: To cool a gipsy's lust.

speaker: PHILO
text_entry: Flourish. Enter ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, her Ladies, the Train, with Eunuchs fanning her

speaker: PHILO
text_entry: Look, where they come:

speaker: PHILO
text_entry: Take but good note, and you shall see in him.

speaker: PHILO
text_entry: The triple pillar of the world transform'd

speaker: PHILO
text_entry: Into a strumpet's fool: behold and see.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: If it be love indeed, tell me how much.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: There's beggary in the love that can be reckon'd.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I'll set a bourn how far to be beloved.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Then must thou needs find out new heaven, new earth.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Enter an Attendant

speaker: Attendant
text_entry: News, my good lord, from Rome.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Grates me: the sum.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Nay, hear them, Antony:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Fulvia perchance is angry; or, who knows

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: If the scarce-bearded Caesar have not sent

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: His powerful mandate to you, 'Do this, or this;

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Take in that kingdom, and enfranchise that;

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Perform 't, or else we damn thee.'

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: How, my love!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Perchance! nay, and most like:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: You must not stay here longer, your dismission

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Is come from Caesar; therefore hear it, Antony.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Where's Fulvia's process? Caesar's I would say? both?

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Call in the messengers. As I am Egypt's queen,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Thou blushest, Antony; and that blood of thine

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Is Caesar's homager: else so thy cheek pays shame

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: When shrill-tongued Fulvia scolds. The messengers!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Let Rome in Tiber melt, and the wide arch

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Of the ranged empire fall! Here is my space.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Kingdoms are clay: our dungy earth alike

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Feeds beast as man: the nobleness of life

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Is to do thus; when such a mutual pair

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Embracing

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And such a twain can do't, in which I bind,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: On pain of punishment, the world to weet

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: We stand up peerless.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Excellent falsehood!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Why did he marry Fulvia, and not love her?

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I'll seem the fool I am not; Antony

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Will be himself.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: But stirr'd by Cleopatra.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Now, for the love of Love and her soft hours,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Let's not confound the time with conference harsh:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: There's not a minute of our lives should stretch

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Without some pleasure now. What sport tonight?

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Hear the ambassadors.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Fie, wrangling queen!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Whom every thing becomes, to chide, to laugh,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To weep; whose every passion fully strives

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To make itself, in thee, fair and admired!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: No messenger, but thine; and all alone

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To-night we'll wander through the streets and note

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The qualities of people. Come, my queen;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Last night you did desire it: speak not to us.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Exeunt MARK ANTONY and CLEOPATRA with their train

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Is Caesar with Antonius prized so slight?

speaker: PHILO
text_entry: Sir, sometimes, when he is not Antony,

speaker: PHILO
text_entry: He comes too short of that great property

speaker: PHILO
text_entry: Which still should go with Antony.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: I am full sorry

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: That he approves the common liar, who

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Thus speaks of him at Rome: but I will hope

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Of better deeds to-morrow. Rest you happy!

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: SCENE II. The same. Another room.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Enter CHARMIAN, IRAS, ALEXAS, and a Soothsayer

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Lord Alexas, sweet Alexas, most any thing Alexas,

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: almost most absolute Alexas, where's the soothsayer

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: that you praised so to the queen? O, that I knew

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: this husband, which, you say, must charge his horns

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: with garlands!

speaker: ALEXAS
text_entry: Soothsayer!

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: Your will?

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Is this the man? Is't you, sir, that know things?

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: In nature's infinite book of secrecy

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: A little I can read.

speaker: ALEXAS
text_entry: Show him your hand.

speaker: ALEXAS
text_entry: Enter DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Bring in the banquet quickly; wine enough

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Cleopatra's health to drink.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Good sir, give me good fortune.

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: I make not, but foresee.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Pray, then, foresee me one.

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: You shall be yet far fairer than you are.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: He means in flesh.

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: No, you shall paint when you are old.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Wrinkles forbid!

speaker: ALEXAS
text_entry: Vex not his prescience; be attentive.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Hush!

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: You shall be more beloving than beloved.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: I had rather heat my liver with drinking.

speaker: ALEXAS
text_entry: Nay, hear him.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Good now, some excellent fortune! Let me be married

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: to three kings in a forenoon, and widow them all:

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: let me have a child at fifty, to whom Herod of Jewry

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: may do homage: find me to marry me with Octavius

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Caesar, and companion me with my mistress.

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: You shall outlive the lady whom you serve.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: O excellent! I love long life better than figs.

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: You have seen and proved a fairer former fortune

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: Than that which is to approach.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Then belike my children shall have no names:

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: prithee, how many boys and wenches must I have?

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: If every of your wishes had a womb.

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: And fertile every wish, a million.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Out, fool! I forgive thee for a witch.

speaker: ALEXAS
text_entry: You think none but your sheets are privy to your wishes.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Nay, come, tell Iras hers.

speaker: ALEXAS
text_entry: We'll know all our fortunes.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Mine, and most of our fortunes, to-night, shall

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: be--drunk to bed.

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: There's a palm presages chastity, if nothing else.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: E'en as the o'erflowing Nilus presageth famine.

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: Go, you wild bedfellow, you cannot soothsay.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Nay, if an oily palm be not a fruitful

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: prognostication, I cannot scratch mine ear. Prithee,

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: tell her but a worky-day fortune.

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: Your fortunes are alike.

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: But how, but how? give me particulars.

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: I have said.

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: Am I not an inch of fortune better than she?

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Well, if you were but an inch of fortune better than

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: I, where would you choose it?

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: Not in my husband's nose.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Our worser thoughts heavens mend! Alexas,--come,

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: his fortune, his fortune! O, let him marry a woman

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: that cannot go, sweet Isis, I beseech thee! and let

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: her die too, and give him a worse! and let worst

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: follow worse, till the worst of all follow him

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: laughing to his grave, fifty-fold a cuckold! Good

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Isis, hear me this prayer, though thou deny me a

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: matter of more weight; good Isis, I beseech thee!

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: Amen. Dear goddess, hear that prayer of the people!

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: for, as it is a heartbreaking to see a handsome man

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: loose-wived, so it is a deadly sorrow to behold a

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: foul knave uncuckolded: therefore, dear Isis, keep

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: decorum, and fortune him accordingly!

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Amen.

speaker: ALEXAS
text_entry: Lo, now, if it lay in their hands to make me a

speaker: ALEXAS
text_entry: cuckold, they would make themselves whores, but

speaker: ALEXAS
text_entry: they'ld do't!

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Hush! here comes Antony.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Not he; the queen.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Enter CLEOPATRA

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Saw you my lord?

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: No, lady.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Was he not here?

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: No, madam.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: He was disposed to mirth; but on the sudden

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: A Roman thought hath struck him. Enobarbus!

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Madam?

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Seek him, and bring him hither.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Where's Alexas?

speaker: ALEXAS
text_entry: Here, at your service. My lord approaches.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: We will not look upon him: go with us.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Enter MARK ANTONY with a Messenger and Attendants

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Fulvia thy wife first came into the field.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Against my brother Lucius?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Ay:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: But soon that war had end, and the time's state

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Made friends of them, joining their force 'gainst Caesar;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Whose better issue in the war, from Italy,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Upon the first encounter, drave them.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Well, what worst?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The nature of bad news infects the teller.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: When it concerns the fool or coward. On:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Things that are past are done with me. 'Tis thus:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Who tells me true, though in his tale lie death,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I hear him as he flatter'd.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Labienus--

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: This is stiff news--hath, with his Parthian force,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Extended Asia from Euphrates;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: His conquering banner shook from Syria

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: To Lydia and to Ionia; Whilst--

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Antony, thou wouldst say,--

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: O, my lord!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Speak to me home, mince not the general tongue:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Name Cleopatra as she is call'd in Rome;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Rail thou in Fulvia's phrase; and taunt my faults

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: With such full licence as both truth and malice

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Have power to utter. O, then we bring forth weeds,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: When our quick minds lie still; and our ills told us

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Is as our earing. Fare thee well awhile.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: At your noble pleasure.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Exit

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: From Sicyon, ho, the news! Speak there!

speaker: First Attendant
text_entry: The man from Sicyon,--is there such an one?

speaker: Second Attendant
text_entry: He stays upon your will.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Let him appear.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: These strong Egyptian fetters I must break,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Or lose myself in dotage.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Enter another Messenger

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: What are you?

speaker: Second Messenger
text_entry: Fulvia thy wife is dead.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Where died she?

speaker: Second Messenger
text_entry: In Sicyon:

speaker: Second Messenger
text_entry: Her length of sickness, with what else more serious

speaker: Second Messenger
text_entry: Importeth thee to know, this bears.

speaker: Second Messenger
text_entry: Gives a letter

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Forbear me.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Exit Second Messenger

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: There's a great spirit gone! Thus did I desire it:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: What our contempt doth often hurl from us,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: We wish it ours again; the present pleasure,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: By revolution lowering, does become

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The opposite of itself: she's good, being gone;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The hand could pluck her back that shoved her on.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I must from this enchanting queen break off:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Ten thousand harms, more than the ills I know,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: My idleness doth hatch. How now! Enobarbus!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Re-enter DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: What's your pleasure, sir?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I must with haste from hence.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Why, then, we kill all our women:

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: we see how mortal an unkindness is to them;

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: if they suffer our departure, death's the word.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I must be gone.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Under a compelling occasion, let women die; it were

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: pity to cast them away for nothing; though, between

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: them and a great cause, they should be esteemed

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: nothing. Cleopatra, catching but the least noise of

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: this, dies instantly; I have seen her die twenty

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: times upon far poorer moment: I do think there is

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: mettle in death, which commits some loving act upon

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: her, she hath such a celerity in dying.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: She is cunning past man's thought.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Exit ALEXAS

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Alack, sir, no; her passions are made of nothing but

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: the finest part of pure love: we cannot call her

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: winds and waters sighs and tears; they are greater

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: storms and tempests than almanacs can report: this

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: cannot be cunning in her; if it be, she makes a

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: shower of rain as well as Jove.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Would I had never seen her.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: O, sir, you had then left unseen a wonderful piece

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: of work; which not to have been blest withal would

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: have discredited your travel.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Fulvia is dead.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Sir?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Fulvia is dead.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Fulvia!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Dead.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Why, sir, give the gods a thankful sacrifice. When

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: it pleaseth their deities to take the wife of a man

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: from him, it shows to man the tailors of the earth;

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: comforting therein, that when old robes are worn

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: out, there are members to make new. If there were

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: no more women but Fulvia, then had you indeed a cut,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: and the case to be lamented: this grief is crowned

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: with consolation; your old smock brings forth a new

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: petticoat: and indeed the tears live in an onion

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: that should water this sorrow.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The business she hath broached in the state

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Cannot endure my absence.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: And the business you have broached here cannot be

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: without you; especially that of Cleopatra's, which

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: wholly depends on your abode.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: No more light answers. Let our officers

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Have notice what we purpose. I shall break

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The cause of our expedience to the queen,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And get her leave to part. For not alone

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The death of Fulvia, with more urgent touches,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Do strongly speak to us; but the letters too

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Of many our contriving friends in Rome

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Petition us at home: Sextus Pompeius

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Hath given the dare to Caesar, and commands

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The empire of the sea: our slippery people,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Whose love is never link'd to the deserver

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Till his deserts are past, begin to throw

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Pompey the Great and all his dignities

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Upon his son; who, high in name and power,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Higher than both in blood and life, stands up

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: For the main soldier: whose quality, going on,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The sides o' the world may danger: much is breeding,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Which, like the courser's hair, hath yet but life,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And not a serpent's poison. Say, our pleasure,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To such whose place is under us, requires

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Our quick remove from hence.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: I shall do't.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: SCENE III. The same. Another room.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and ALEXAS

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Where is he?

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: I did not see him since.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: See where he is, who's with him, what he does:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I did not send you: if you find him sad,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Say I am dancing; if in mirth, report

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: That I am sudden sick: quick, and return.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Exit ALEXAS

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Madam, methinks, if you did love him dearly,

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: You do not hold the method to enforce

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: The like from him.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: What should I do, I do not?

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: In each thing give him way, cross him nothing.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Thou teachest like a fool; the way to lose him.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Tempt him not so too far; I wish, forbear:

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: In time we hate that which we often fear.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: But here comes Antony.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Enter MARK ANTONY

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I am sick and sullen.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I am sorry to give breathing to my purpose,--

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Help me away, dear Charmian; I shall fall:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: It cannot be thus long, the sides of nature

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Will not sustain it.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Now, my dearest queen,--

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Pray you, stand further from me.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: What's the matter?

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I know, by that same eye, there's some good news.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: What says the married woman? You may go:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Would she had never given you leave to come!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Let her not say 'tis I that keep you here:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I have no power upon you; hers you are.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The gods best know,--

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: O, never was there queen

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: So mightily betray'd! yet at the first

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I saw the treasons planted.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Cleopatra,--

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Why should I think you can be mine and true,

text_entry: It nothing ill becomes thee.

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: Aboard my galley I invite you all:

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: Will you lead, lords?

speaker: LEPIDUS
text_entry: Show us the way, sir.

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: Come.

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: Exeunt all but MENAS and ENOBARBUS

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: [Aside]  Thy father, Pompey, would ne'er have

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: made this treaty.--You and I have known, sir.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: At sea, I think.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: We have, sir.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: You have done well by water.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: And you by land.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: I will praise any man that will praise me; though it

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: cannot be denied what I have done by land.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Nor what I have done by water.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Yes, something you can deny for your own

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: safety: you have been a great thief by sea.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: And you by land.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: There I deny my land service. But give me your

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: hand, Menas: if our eyes had authority, here they

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: might take two thieves kissing.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: All men's faces are true, whatsome'er their hands are.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: But there is never a fair woman has a true face.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: No slander; they steal hearts.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: We came hither to fight with you.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: For my part, I am sorry it is turned to a drinking.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Pompey doth this day laugh away his fortune.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: If he do, sure, he cannot weep't back again.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: You've said, sir. We looked not for Mark Antony

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: here: pray you, is he married to Cleopatra?

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Caesar's sister is called Octavia.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: True, sir; she was the wife of Caius Marcellus.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: But she is now the wife of Marcus Antonius.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Pray ye, sir?

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: 'Tis true.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Then is Caesar and he for ever knit together.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: If I were bound to divine of this unity, I would

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: not prophesy so.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: I think the policy of that purpose made more in the

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: marriage than the love of the parties.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: I think so too. But you shall find, the band that

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: seems to tie their friendship together will be the

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: very strangler of their amity: Octavia is of a

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: holy, cold, and still conversation.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Who would not have his wife so?

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Not he that himself is not so; which is Mark Antony.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: He will to his Egyptian dish again: then shall the

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: sighs of Octavia blow the fire up in Caesar; and, as

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: I said before, that which is the strength of their

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: amity shall prove the immediate author of their

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: variance. Antony will use his affection where it is:

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: he married but his occasion here.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: And thus it may be. Come, sir, will you aboard?

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: I have a health for you.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: I shall take it, sir: we have used our throats in Egypt.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Come, let's away.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: SCENE VII. On board POMPEY's galley, off Misenum.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Music plays. Enter two or three Servants with a banquet

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Here they'll be, man. Some o' their plants are

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: ill-rooted already: the least wind i' the world

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: will blow them down.

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: Lepidus is high-coloured.

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: They have made him drink alms-drink.

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: As they pinch one another by the disposition, he

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: cries out 'No more;' reconciles them to his

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: entreaty, and himself to the drink.

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: But it raises the greater war between him and

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: his discretion.

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: Why, this is to have a name in great men's

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: fellowship: I had as lief have a reed that will do

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: me no service as a partisan I could not heave.

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: To be called into a huge sphere, and not to be seen

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: to move in't, are the holes where eyes should be,

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: which pitifully disaster the cheeks.

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: A sennet sounded. Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR, MARK  ANTONY, LEPIDUS, POMPEY, AGRIPPA, MECAENAS, DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS, MENAS, with other captains

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: [To OCTAVIUS CAESAR]  Thus do they, sir: they take

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: the flow o' the Nile

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: By certain scales i' the pyramid; they know,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: By the height, the lowness, or the mean, if dearth

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Or foison follow: the higher Nilus swells,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The more it promises: as it ebbs, the seedsman

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Upon the slime and ooze scatters his grain,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And shortly comes to harvest.

speaker: LEPIDUS
text_entry: You've strange serpents there.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Ay, Lepidus.

speaker: LEPIDUS
text_entry: Your serpent of Egypt is bred now of your mud by the

speaker: LEPIDUS
text_entry: operation of your sun: so is your crocodile.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: They are so.

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: Sit,--and some wine! A health to Lepidus!

speaker: LEPIDUS
text_entry: I am not so well as I should be, but I'll ne'er out.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Not till you have slept; I fear me you'll be in till then.

speaker: LEPIDUS
text_entry: Nay, certainly, I have heard the Ptolemies'

speaker: LEPIDUS
text_entry: pyramises are very goodly things; without

speaker: LEPIDUS
text_entry: contradiction, I have heard that.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: [Aside to POMPEY]  Pompey, a word.

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: [Aside to MENAS]                 Say in mine ear:

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: what is't?

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: [Aside to POMPEY]  Forsake thy seat, I do beseech

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: thee, captain,

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: And hear me speak a word.

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: [Aside to MENAS]  Forbear me till anon.

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: This wine for Lepidus!

speaker: LEPIDUS
text_entry: What manner o' thing is your crocodile?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: It is shaped, sir, like itself; and it is as broad

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: as it hath breadth: it is just so high as it is,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: and moves with its own organs: it lives by that

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: which nourisheth it; and the elements once out of

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: it, it transmigrates.

speaker: LEPIDUS
text_entry: What colour is it of?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Of it own colour too.

speaker: LEPIDUS
text_entry: 'Tis a strange serpent.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: 'Tis so. And the tears of it are wet.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Will this description satisfy him?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: With the health that Pompey gives him, else he is a

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: very epicure.

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: [Aside to MENAS]  Go hang, sir, hang! Tell me of

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: that? away!

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: Do as I bid you. Where's this cup I call'd for?

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: [Aside to POMPEY]  If for the sake of merit thou

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: wilt hear me,

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Rise from thy stool.

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: [Aside to MENAS]  I think thou'rt mad.

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: The matter?

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: Rises, and walks aside

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: I have ever held my cap off to thy fortunes.

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: Thou hast served me with much faith. What's else to say?

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: Be jolly, lords.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: These quick-sands, Lepidus,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Keep off them, for you sink.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Wilt thou be lord of all the world?

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: What say'st thou?

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Wilt thou be lord of the whole world? That's twice.

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: How should that be?

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: But entertain it,

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: And, though thou think me poor, I am the man

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Will give thee all the world.

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: Hast thou drunk well?

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Now, Pompey, I have kept me from the cup.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Thou art, if thou darest be, the earthly Jove:

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Whate'er the ocean pales, or sky inclips,

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Is thine, if thou wilt ha't.

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: Show me which way.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: These three world-sharers, these competitors,

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Are in thy vessel: let me cut the cable;

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: And, when we are put off, fall to their throats:

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: All there is thine.

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: Ah, this thou shouldst have done,

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: And not have spoke on't! In me 'tis villany;

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: In thee't had been good service. Thou must know,

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: 'Tis not my profit that does lead mine honour;

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: Mine honour, it. Repent that e'er thy tongue

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: Hath so betray'd thine act: being done unknown,

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: I should have found it afterwards well done;

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: But must condemn it now. Desist, and drink.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: [Aside]  For this,

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: I'll never follow thy pall'd fortunes more.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Who seeks, and will not take when once 'tis offer'd,

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Shall never find it more.

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: This health to Lepidus!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Bear him ashore. I'll pledge it for him, Pompey.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Here's to thee, Menas!

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Enobarbus, welcome!

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: Fill till the cup be hid.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: There's a strong fellow, Menas.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Pointing to the Attendant who carries off LEPIDUS

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Why?

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: A' bears the third part of the world, man; see'st

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: not?

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: The third part, then, is drunk: would it were all,

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: That it might go on wheels!

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Drink thou; increase the reels.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Come.

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: This is not yet an Alexandrian feast.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: It ripens towards it. Strike the vessels, ho?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Here is to Caesar!

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: I could well forbear't.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: It's monstrous labour, when I wash my brain,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: And it grows fouler.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Be a child o' the time.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Possess it, I'll make answer:

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: But I had rather fast from all four days

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Than drink so much in one.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Ha, my brave emperor!

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: To MARK ANTONY

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Shall we dance now the Egyptian Bacchanals,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: And celebrate our drink?

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: Let's ha't, good soldier.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Come, let's all take hands,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Till that the conquering wine hath steep'd our sense

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: In soft and delicate Lethe.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: All take hands.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Make battery to our ears with the loud music:

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: The while I'll place you: then the boy shall sing;

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: The holding every man shall bear as loud

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: As his strong sides can volley.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Music plays. DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS places them hand in hand

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: THE SONG.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Come, thou monarch of the vine,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Plumpy Bacchus with pink eyne!

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: In thy fats our cares be drown'd,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: With thy grapes our hairs be crown'd:

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Cup us, till the world go round,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Cup us, till the world go round!

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: What would you more? Pompey, good night. Good brother,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Let me request you off: our graver business

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Frowns at this levity. Gentle lords, let's part;

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: You see we have burnt our cheeks: strong Enobarb

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Is weaker than the wine; and mine own tongue

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Splits what it speaks: the wild disguise hath almost

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Antick'd us all. What needs more words? Good night.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Good Antony, your hand.

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: I'll try you on the shore.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And shall, sir; give's your hand.

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: O Antony,

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: You have my father's house,--But, what? we are friends.

speaker: POMPEY
text_entry: Come, down into the boat.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Take heed you fall not.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Exeunt all but DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS and MENAS

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Menas, I'll not on shore.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: No, to my cabin.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: These drums! these trumpets, flutes! what!

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Let Neptune hear we bid a loud farewell

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: To these great fellows: sound and be hang'd, sound out!

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Sound a flourish, with drums

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Ho! says a' There's my cap.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Ho! Noble captain, come.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: SCENE I. A plain in Syria.

speaker: MENAS
text_entry: Enter VENTIDIUS as it were in triumph, with SILIUS,  and other Romans, Officers, and Soldiers; the dead body of PACORUS borne before him

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Now, darting Parthia, art thou struck; and now

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Pleased fortune does of Marcus Crassus' death

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Make me revenger. Bear the king's son's body

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Before our army. Thy Pacorus, Orodes,

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Pays this for Marcus Crassus.

speaker: SILIUS
text_entry: Noble Ventidius,

speaker: SILIUS
text_entry: Whilst yet with Parthian blood thy sword is warm,

speaker: SILIUS
text_entry: The fugitive Parthians follow; spur through Media,

speaker: SILIUS
text_entry: Mesopotamia, and the shelters whither

speaker: SILIUS
text_entry: The routed fly: so thy grand captain Antony

speaker: SILIUS
text_entry: Shall set thee on triumphant chariots and

speaker: SILIUS
text_entry: Put garlands on thy head.

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: O Silius, Silius,

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: I have done enough; a lower place, note well,

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: May make too great an act: for learn this, Silius;

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Better to leave undone, than by our deed

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Acquire too high a fame when him we serve's away.

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Caesar and Antony have ever won

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: More in their officer than person: Sossius,

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: One of my place in Syria, his lieutenant,

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: For quick accumulation of renown,

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Which he achieved by the minute, lost his favour.

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Who does i' the wars more than his captain can

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Becomes his captain's captain: and ambition,

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: The soldier's virtue, rather makes choice of loss,

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Than gain which darkens him.

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: I could do more to do Antonius good,

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: But 'twould offend him; and in his offence

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Should my performance perish.

speaker: SILIUS
text_entry: Thou hast, Ventidius,

speaker: SILIUS
text_entry: that

speaker: SILIUS
text_entry: Without the which a soldier, and his sword,

speaker: SILIUS
text_entry: Grants scarce distinction. Thou wilt write to Antony!

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: I'll humbly signify what in his name,

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: That magical word of war, we have effected;

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: How, with his banners and his well-paid ranks,

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: The ne'er-yet-beaten horse of Parthia

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: We have jaded out o' the field.

speaker: SILIUS
text_entry: Where is he now?

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: He purposeth to Athens: whither, with what haste

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: The weight we must convey with's will permit,

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: We shall appear before him. On there; pass along!

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: SCENE II. Rome. An ante-chamber in OCTAVIUS CAESAR's house.

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Enter AGRIPPA at one door, DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS at another

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: What, are the brothers parted?

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: They have dispatch'd with Pompey, he is gone;

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: The other three are sealing. Octavia weeps

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: To part from Rome; Caesar is sad; and Lepidus,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Since Pompey's feast, as Menas says, is troubled

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: With the green sickness.

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: 'Tis a noble Lepidus.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: A very fine one: O, how he loves Caesar!

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: Nay, but how dearly he adores Mark Antony!

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Caesar? Why, he's the Jupiter of men.

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: What's Antony? The god of Jupiter.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Spake you of Caesar? How! the non-pareil!

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: O Antony! O thou Arabian bird!

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Would you praise Caesar, say 'Caesar:' go no further.

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: Indeed, he plied them both with excellent praises.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: But he loves Caesar best; yet he loves Antony:

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Ho! hearts, tongues, figures, scribes, bards,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: poets, cannot

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Think, speak, cast, write, sing, number, ho!

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: His love to Antony. But as for Caesar,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Kneel down, kneel down, and wonder.

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: Both he loves.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: They are his shards, and he their beetle.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Trumpets within

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: So;

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: This is to horse. Adieu, noble Agrippa.

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: Good fortune, worthy soldier; and farewell.

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR, MARK ANTONY, LEPIDUS, and OCTAVIA

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: No further, sir.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: You take from me a great part of myself;

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Use me well in 't. Sister, prove such a wife

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: As my thoughts make thee, and as my farthest band

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Shall pass on thy approof. Most noble Antony,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Let not the piece of virtue, which is set

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Betwixt us as the cement of our love,

text_entry: What is't you say?

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Your presence needs must puzzle Antony;

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Take from his heart, take from his brain,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: from's time,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: What should not then be spared. He is already

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Traduced for levity; and 'tis said in Rome

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: That Photinus an eunuch and your maids

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Manage this war.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Sink Rome, and their tongues rot

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: That speak against us! A charge we bear i' the war,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: And, as the president of my kingdom, will

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Appear there for a man. Speak not against it:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I will not stay behind.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Nay, I have done.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Here comes the emperor.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Enter MARK ANTONY and CANIDIUS

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Is it not strange, Canidius,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: That from Tarentum and Brundusium

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: He could so quickly cut the Ionian sea,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And take in Toryne? You have heard on't, sweet?

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Celerity is never more admired

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Than by the negligent.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: A good rebuke,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Which might have well becomed the best of men,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To taunt at slackness. Canidius, we

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Will fight with him by sea.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: By sea! what else?

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Why will my lord do so?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: For that he dares us to't.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: So hath my lord dared him to single fight.

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Ay, and to wage this battle at Pharsalia.

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Where Caesar fought with Pompey: but these offers,

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Which serve not for his vantage, be shakes off;

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: And so should you.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Your ships are not well mann'd;

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Your mariners are muleters, reapers, people

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Ingross'd by swift impress; in Caesar's fleet

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Are those that often have 'gainst Pompey fought:

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Their ships are yare; yours, heavy: no disgrace

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Shall fall you for refusing him at sea,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Being prepared for land.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: By sea, by sea.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Most worthy sir, you therein throw away

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: The absolute soldiership you have by land;

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Distract your army, which doth most consist

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Of war-mark'd footmen; leave unexecuted

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Your own renowned knowledge; quite forego

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: The way which promises assurance; and

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Give up yourself merely to chance and hazard,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: From firm security.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I'll fight at sea.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I have sixty sails, Caesar none better.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Our overplus of shipping will we burn;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And, with the rest full-mann'd, from the head of Actium

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Beat the approaching Caesar. But if we fail,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: We then can do't at land.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Thy business?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The news is true, my lord; he is descried;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Caesar has taken Toryne.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Can he be there in person? 'tis impossible;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Strange that power should be. Canidius,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Our nineteen legions thou shalt hold by land,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And our twelve thousand horse. We'll to our ship:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Away, my Thetis!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Enter a Soldier

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: How now, worthy soldier?

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: O noble emperor, do not fight by sea;

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: Trust not to rotten planks: do you misdoubt

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: This sword and these my wounds? Let the Egyptians

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: And the Phoenicians go a-ducking; we

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: Have used to conquer, standing on the earth,

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: And fighting foot to foot.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Well, well: away!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Exeunt MARK ANTONY, QUEEN CLEOPATRA, and DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: By Hercules, I think I am i' the right.

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Soldier, thou art: but his whole action grows

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Not in the power on't: so our leader's led,

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: And we are women's men.

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: You keep by land

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: The legions and the horse whole, do you not?

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Marcus Octavius, Marcus Justeius,

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Publicola, and Caelius, are for sea:

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: But we keep whole by land. This speed of Caesar's

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Carries beyond belief.

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: While he was yet in Rome,

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: His power went out in such distractions as

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: Beguiled all spies.

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Who's his lieutenant, hear you?

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: They say, one Taurus.

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Well I know the man.

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The emperor calls Canidius.

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: With news the time's with labour, and throes forth,

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Each minute, some.

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: SCENE VIII. A plain near Actium.

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR, and TAURUS, with his army, marching

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Taurus!

speaker: TAURUS
text_entry: My lord?

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Strike not by land; keep whole: provoke not battle,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Till we have done at sea. Do not exceed

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: The prescript of this scroll: our fortune lies

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Upon this jump.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: SCENE IX. Another part of the plain.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Enter MARK ANTONY and DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Set we our squadrons on yond side o' the hill,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: In eye of Caesar's battle; from which place

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: We may the number of the ships behold,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And so proceed accordingly.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: SCENE X. Another part of the plain.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: CANIDIUS marcheth with his land army one way over  the stage; and TAURUS, the lieutenant of OCTAVIUS  CAESAR, the other way. After their going in, is heard the noise of a sea-fight

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Alarum. Enter DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Naught, naught all, naught! I can behold no longer:

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: The Antoniad, the Egyptian admiral,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: With all their sixty, fly and turn the rudder:

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: To see't mine eyes are blasted.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Enter SCARUS

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: Gods and goddesses,

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: All the whole synod of them!

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: What's thy passion!

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: The greater cantle of the world is lost

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: With very ignorance; we have kiss'd away

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: Kingdoms and provinces.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: How appears the fight?

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: On our side like the token'd pestilence,

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: Where death is sure. Yon ribaudred nag of Egypt,--

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: Whom leprosy o'ertake!--i' the midst o' the fight,

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: When vantage like a pair of twins appear'd,

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: Both as the same, or rather ours the elder,

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: The breese upon her, like a cow in June,

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: Hoists sails and flies.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: That I beheld:

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Mine eyes did sicken at the sight, and could not

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Endure a further view.

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: She once being loof'd,

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: The noble ruin of her magic, Antony,

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: Claps on his sea-wing, and, like a doting mallard,

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: Leaving the fight in height, flies after her:

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: I never saw an action of such shame;

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: Experience, manhood, honour, ne'er before

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: Did violate so itself.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Alack, alack!

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Enter CANIDIUS

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Our fortune on the sea is out of breath,

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: And sinks most lamentably. Had our general

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Been what he knew himself, it had gone well:

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: O, he has given example for our flight,

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Most grossly, by his own!

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Ay, are you thereabouts?

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Why, then, good night indeed.

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Toward Peloponnesus are they fled.

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: 'Tis easy to't; and there I will attend

speaker: SCARUS
text_entry: What further comes.

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: To Caesar will I render

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: My legions and my horse: six kings already

speaker: CANIDIUS
text_entry: Show me the way of yielding.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: I'll yet follow

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: The wounded chance of Antony, though my reason

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Sits in the wind against me.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: SCENE XI. Alexandria. CLEOPATRA's palace.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Enter MARK ANTONY with Attendants

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Hark! the land bids me tread no more upon't;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: It is ashamed to bear me! Friends, come hither:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I am so lated in the world, that I

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Have lost my way for ever: I have a ship

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Laden with gold; take that, divide it; fly,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And make your peace with Caesar.

speaker: All
text_entry: Fly! not we.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I have fled myself; and have instructed cowards

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To run and show their shoulders. Friends, be gone;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I have myself resolved upon a course

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Which has no need of you; be gone:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: My treasure's in the harbour, take it. O,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I follow'd that I blush to look upon:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: My very hairs do mutiny; for the white

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Reprove the brown for rashness, and they them

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: For fear and doting. Friends, be gone: you shall

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Have letters from me to some friends that will

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Sweep your way for you. Pray you, look not sad,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Nor make replies of loathness: take the hint

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Which my despair proclaims; let that be left

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Which leaves itself: to the sea-side straightway:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I will possess you of that ship and treasure.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Leave me, I pray, a little: pray you now:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Nay, do so; for, indeed, I have lost command,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Therefore I pray you: I'll see you by and by.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Sits down

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Enter CLEOPATRA led by CHARMIAN and IRAS; EROS following

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Nay, gentle madam, to him, comfort him.

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: Do, most dear queen.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Do! why: what else?

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Let me sit down. O Juno!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: No, no, no, no, no.

speaker: EROS
text_entry: See you here, sir?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: O fie, fie, fie!

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Madam!

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: Madam, O good empress!

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Sir, sir,--

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Yes, my lord, yes; he at Philippi kept

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: His sword e'en like a dancer; while I struck

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The lean and wrinkled Cassius; and 'twas I

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: That the mad Brutus ended: he alone

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Dealt on lieutenantry, and no practise had

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: In the brave squares of war: yet now--No matter.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Ah, stand by.

speaker: EROS
text_entry: The queen, my lord, the queen.

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: Go to him, madam, speak to him:

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: He is unqualitied with very shame.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Well then, sustain him: O!

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Most noble sir, arise; the queen approaches:

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Her head's declined, and death will seize her, but

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Your comfort makes the rescue.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I have offended reputation,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: A most unnoble swerving.

speaker: EROS
text_entry: Sir, the queen.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: O, whither hast thou led me, Egypt? See,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: How I convey my shame out of thine eyes

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: By looking back what I have left behind

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: 'Stroy'd in dishonour.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: O my lord, my lord,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Forgive my fearful sails! I little thought

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: You would have follow'd.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Egypt, thou knew'st too well

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: My heart was to thy rudder tied by the strings,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And thou shouldst tow me after: o'er my spirit

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Thy full supremacy thou knew'st, and that

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Thy beck might from the bidding of the gods

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Command me.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: O, my pardon!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Now I must

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To the young man send humble treaties, dodge

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And palter in the shifts of lowness; who

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: With half the bulk o' the world play'd as I pleased,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Making and marring fortunes. You did know

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: How much you were my conqueror; and that

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: My sword, made weak by my affection, would

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Obey it on all cause.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Pardon, pardon!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Fall not a tear, I say; one of them rates

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: All that is won and lost: give me a kiss;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Even this repays me. We sent our schoolmaster;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Is he come back? Love, I am full of lead.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Some wine, within there, and our viands! Fortune knows

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: We scorn her most when most she offers blows.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: SCENE XII. Egypt. OCTAVIUS CAESAR's camp.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR, DOLABELLA, THYREUS, with others

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Let him appear that's come from Antony.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Know you him?

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Caesar, 'tis his schoolmaster:

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: An argument that he is pluck'd, when hither

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: He sends so poor a pinion off his wing,

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Which had superfluous kings for messengers

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Not many moons gone by.

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Enter EUPHRONIUS, ambassador from MARK ANTONY

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Approach, and speak.

speaker: EUPHRONIUS
text_entry: Such as I am, I come from Antony:

speaker: EUPHRONIUS
text_entry: I was of late as petty to his ends

speaker: EUPHRONIUS
text_entry: As is the morn-dew on the myrtle-leaf

speaker: EUPHRONIUS
text_entry: To his grand sea.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Be't so: declare thine office.

speaker: EUPHRONIUS
text_entry: Lord of his fortunes he salutes thee, and

speaker: EUPHRONIUS
text_entry: Requires to live in Egypt: which not granted,

speaker: EUPHRONIUS
text_entry: He lessens his requests; and to thee sues

speaker: EUPHRONIUS
text_entry: To let him breathe between the heavens and earth,

speaker: EUPHRONIUS
text_entry: A private man in Athens: this for him.

speaker: EUPHRONIUS
text_entry: Next, Cleopatra does confess thy greatness;

speaker: EUPHRONIUS
text_entry: Submits her to thy might; and of thee craves

speaker: EUPHRONIUS
text_entry: The circle of the Ptolemies for her heirs,

speaker: EUPHRONIUS
text_entry: Now hazarded to thy grace.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: For Antony,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: I have no ears to his request. The queen

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Of audience nor desire shall fail, so she

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: From Egypt drive her all-disgraced friend,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Or take his life there: this if she perform,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: She shall not sue unheard. So to them both.

speaker: EUPHRONIUS
text_entry: Fortune pursue thee!

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Bring him through the bands.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Exit EUPHRONIUS

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: To THYREUS

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: From Antony win Cleopatra: promise,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: And in our name, what she requires; add more,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: From thine invention, offers: women are not

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: In their best fortunes strong; but want will perjure

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: The ne'er touch'd vestal: try thy cunning, Thyreus;

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Make thine own edict for thy pains, which we

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Will answer as a law.

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: Caesar, I go.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Observe how Antony becomes his flaw,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: And what thou think'st his very action speaks

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: In every power that moves.

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: Caesar, I shall.

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: SCENE XIII. Alexandria. CLEOPATRA's palace.

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: Enter CLEOPATRA, DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS, CHARMIAN, and IRAS

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: What shall we do, Enobarbus?

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Think, and die.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Is Antony or we in fault for this?

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Antony only, that would make his will

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Lord of his reason. What though you fled

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: From that great face of war, whose several ranges

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Frighted each other? why should he follow?

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: The itch of his affection should not then

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Have nick'd his captainship; at such a point,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: When half to half the world opposed, he being

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: The meered question: 'twas a shame no less

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Than was his loss, to course your flying flags,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: And leave his navy gazing.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Prithee, peace.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Enter MARK ANTONY with EUPHRONIUS, the Ambassador

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Is that his answer?

speaker: EUPHRONIUS
text_entry: Ay, my lord.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The queen shall then have courtesy, so she

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Will yield us up.

speaker: EUPHRONIUS
text_entry: He says so.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Let her know't.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To the boy Caesar send this grizzled head,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And he will fill thy wishes to the brim

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: With principalities.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: That head, my lord?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To him again: tell him he wears the rose

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Of youth upon him; from which the world should note

speaker: MARK ANTONY

text_entry: [Aside to DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS]  What does he mean?

text_entry: Tend me to-night;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: May be it is the period of your duty:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: A mangled shadow: perchance to-morrow

speaker: MARK ANTONY

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I turn you not away; but, like a master

text_entry: Tend me to-night two hours, I ask no more,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And the gods yield you for't!

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: What mean you, sir,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS

speaker: MARK ANTONY

text_entry: Now the witch take me, if I meant it thus!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: My hearty friends,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: You take me in too dolorous a sense;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: For I spake to you for your comfort; did desire you

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To burn this night with torches: know, my hearts,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I hope well of to-morrow; and will lead you

speaker: MARK ANTONY
